text.text: Welcome to the UIFrameworks Digital Lounge!

blocks.alt_text: A multi-colored outline of two gauges on a black background

text.text: Welcome to the UIFrameworks Digital Lounge! We’ve got an exciting week planned for you. You can find the full schedule of events in the <https://developer.apple.com/news/?id=yy47r7z7| Apple Developer app and on developer.apple.com>, and activities for all lounges kick off on June 7.
If you haven't already, please take a moment to familiarize yourself with <https://developer.apple.com/news/?id=735utu4s|how the Digital Lounges will work>.

We want to make sure these spaces are helpful and welcoming for everyone — developers and Apple employees alike. Please review and follow the <https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/policies/interactive-events/1/Apple-Developer-WWDC22-Interactive-Events-Attendance-Policy.pdf| WWDC22 Interactive Events Policy>.

messages.text:
Welcome, one and all! Welcome to the UIFrameworks Digital Lounge. In just under half an hour, we’ll be kicking off with the _What’s new in UIKit_ watch party. Hop on the UIFrameworks Express, as I and many others will be your guide to explore our very exciting new features and APIs in our UI frameworks in all of our platforms!! :iphone::computer::tv::watch:

There is a lot happening this week, ranging from more watch parties, to Q&A sections, to fun challenges! Don’t go too far, because we’ll be starting right here at 10:05am PST! :face_with_cowboy_hat:

elements.text: Welcome, one and all! Welcome to the UIFrameworks Digital Lounge. In just under half an hour, we’ll be kicking off with the
watch party. Hop on the UIFrameworks Express, as I and many others will be your guide to explore our very exciting new features and APIs in our UI frameworks in all of our platforms!!
There is a lot happening this week, ranging from more watch parties, to Q&A sections, to fun challenges! Don’t go too far, because we’ll be starting right here at 10:05am PST!

messages.text:
Hello there! Welcome to the *What’s new in UIKit* watch party! We are incredibly excited to have everyone join us today. My name is Andy and I’m a UIKit Frameworks Engineer :gear:. In this hour, we invite everyone to watch the video together. Queue up the video, prepare some popcorn :popcorn:, and get ready to hit play at 10:05 PDT.

We are joined today by our fantastic speaker, Dima, as well as many members of the UIKit team, who are all super stoked ready to answer your :question:questions!

There are a lot of people here, so I will be creating threads :thread: associated with each section of the talk as the video progresses so that everyone can chat and ask questions about each individual section. Try your best not to fall behind, or go too far ahead (yes, I’m talking to you 2x speeders). No Spoilers! :face_with_cowboy_hat:

When the video finishes, we’ll have some time left over for additional targeted Q&A, which I’ll explain when we get there. So for the next few minutes, grab your popcorn, get comfortable, and get ready to hit that play :arrow_forward: button!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Does UIFindInteraction work with custom stuff like handwriting?

elements.text: Does UIFindInteraction work with custom stuff like handwriting?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hi!  WKWebView and text view were mentioned, but what about cases in which recycled views are used?  UICollectionView?

elements.text: Hi!  WKWebView and text view were mentioned, but what about cases in which recycled views are used?  UICollectionView?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: UIFindInteraction is build to work with your custom views and with multiple views across you app. It is integrated in UIKit’s text views but you can adopt it for pretty much every view.

elements.text: UIFindInteraction is build to work with your custom views and with multiple views across you app. It is integrated in UIKit’s text views but you can adopt it for pretty much every view.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: More information on `UIFindInteraction` can be learned in the session <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10071/|Adopt desktop class editing interactions>.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
> Does UIFindInteraction work with custom stuff like handwriting?
Echoing what Russell said. You can make this work with handwriting as long as you can convert the drawing to a string first, then provide results to the find interaction.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
> Hi! WKWebView and text view were mentioned, but what about cases in which recycled views are used? UICollectionView?
Yes, UIFindInteraction works well with UICollectionView. As long as your "searchable object" is your model, you can provide results that represent ranges in your model, and when we ask you to decorate these results, you can do so when configuring the cells via content configurations, reloading using diffable data source if necessary.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Hi! WKWebView and text view were mentioned, but what about cases in which recycled views are used? UICollectionView?"}]}

elements.text: Yes, UIFindInteraction works well with UICollectionView. As long as your "searchable object" is your model, you can provide results that represent ranges in your model, and when we ask you to decorate these results, you can do so when configuring the cells via content configurations, reloading using diffable data source if necessary.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Are content configurations and diffable data source a requirement?

elements.text: Are content configurations and diffable data source a requirement?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Nope, that was just a recommendation. You can also decorate cells using `collectionView:cellForItem`, just remember what range we asked you to decorate, and take that into consideration in your data source methods.

elements.text: Nope, that was just a recommendation. You can also decorate cells using
, just remember what range we asked you to decorate, and take that into consideration in your data source methods.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If we support UITextInput in our custom view (and use UITextInteraction for selection, etc.), can we utilize UIFindInteraction?

elements.text: If we support UITextInput in our custom view (and use UITextInteraction for selection, etc.), can we utilize UIFindInteraction?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yes!

Indeed! UIFindInteraction is designed to work well with classes that adopt UITextInput. Take a look at `UITextSearchingFindSession` and `UITextSearching`, or watch my session called "Adopt Desktop-class Editing Interactions".

elements.text: Indeed! UIFindInteraction is designed to work well with classes that adopt UITextInput. Take a look at
, or watch my session called "Adopt Desktop-class Editing Interactions".

slackdump_thread_replies.text: It seems like iOS 16 requires user permission every time the UIPasteboard is accessed. Is there a way for the user to give permission once? This behavior breaks clipboard monitoring.

elements.text: It seems like iOS 16 requires user permission every time the UIPasteboard is accessed. Is there a way for the user to give permission once? This behavior breaks clipboard monitoring.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: That is not possible. If you use system provided paste buttons you will not get the notification but if you programmatically access the pasteboard you can not hide this alert.

elements.text: That is not possible. If you use system provided paste buttons you will not get the notification but if you programmatically access the pasteboard you can not hide this alert.

it depends on the pasteboard content. If there is new content, the alert shows up again.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: <@U03J20E1BPD> to answer your previous question <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uipastecontrol>

messages.text: :scroll: Improved sheets thread :thread:

slackdump_thread_replies.text: This is amazing
Is it possible to adjust the detent height dynamically?  For example, after content is loaded?

elements.text: Is it possible to adjust the detent height dynamically?  For example, after content is loaded?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yes!

Not shown in the slide, you can call `invalidateDetents` on the UISheetPresentationController to cause your custom detents to be re-evaluated at any time. And you can call that inside `sheet.animateChanges { }` to animate it.

elements.text: Not shown in the slide, you can call
on the UISheetPresentationController to cause your custom detents to be re-evaluated at any time. And you can call that inside

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Is there a "size to fit" type of detent, where you can set up constraints and the sheet will fit the content automatically?

elements.text: Is there a "size to fit" type of detent, where you can set up constraints and the sheet will fit the content automatically?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: There’s not. The sheet needs to know the detent height before the sheet content is in the view hierarchy, which also makes it difficult to measure the size of the content except in very simple cases. I welcome feedback reports if this is a use case that’s important to you :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: There’s not. The sheet needs to know the detent height before the sheet content is in the view hierarchy, which also makes it difficult to measure the size of the content except in very simple cases. I welcome feedback reports if this is a use case that’s important to you

They can be configured in the SF Symbols app! The app lets you define which layers in your symbol belong to each hierarchical/palette layer (as well as other fun things like what colors the symbol uses in multicolor mode). Then you can export the symbol with that information included.

You can try it out by cloning one of the built-in symbols as a custom symbol :slightly_smiling_face:

slackdump_thread_replies.text: In a social media app, I have a cache of prepared images for user avatars—since they tend to be fairly large and are displayed frequently, I want to prepare them once and share them across the app. If my app were to have windows on both the builtin display of an iPad at 2x scale and an external display at 1x, I want to make sure I'm using the right scale for computing the pixel size for thumbnail preparation

elements.text: In a social media app, I have a cache of prepared images for user avatars—since they tend to be fairly large and are displayed frequently, I want to prepare them once and share them across the app. If my app were to have windows on both the builtin display of an iPad at 2x scale and an external display at 1x, I want to make sure I'm using the right scale for computing the pixel size for thumbnail preparation

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Each time the image is requested I know where it's going to end up, but I want to avoid the duplicate work of preparing the same image at multiple scales

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yes, that’s the idea: self-sizing cells can now directly request to be resized

elements.text: Yes, that’s the idea: self-sizing cells can now directly request to be resized

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Will be interesting to consider how to use these capabilities, if at all, for apps that support OS versions < 16. :thinking_face:

elements.text: Will be interesting to consider how to use these capabilities, if at all, for apps that support OS versions < 16.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
On iOS 15 and earlier, you request an update to the size of self-sizing cells in UICollectionView and UITableView by:
• If using diffable data source, re-applying the diffable data source’s current snapshot with `animatingDifferences: true`
• If not using diffable data source, performing empty batch updates on the collection or table view directly
Don’t forget on iOS 15, you can use the reconfigure APIs to also update content in the cell too — if the cell needs to be resized that will always happen automatically after you reconfigure it.

The new `selfSizingInvalidation` feature in iOS 16 makes it much easier for cells to directly request a size update, without needing to worry about going to the diffable data source or UICollectionView/UITableView!

<@U03JRN827HN> asked
> We'd like to improve our app & framework to have a better desktop-class experience. For that, we'd like to utilize `UIContextMenuInteraction` and the new `UIEditMenuInteraction`. How should we decide where to use one or the other? Can context menus on iPadOS be presented "in place", like on macOS, without a targeted preview?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"We'd like to improve our app & framework to have a better desktop-class experience. For that, we'd like to utilize `UIContextMenuInteraction` and the new `UIEditMenuInteraction`. How should we decide where to use one or the other? Can context menus on iPadOS be presented \"in place\", like on macOS, without a targeted preview?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: `UIEditMenuInteraction` powers the new light-weight edit menu. With edit menu interaction, on right-click on iPadOS (and macOS), it’ll also automatically present the more compact context menu without a targeted preview. Use Edit menu interaction in contexts where you don’t need a preview, or where the menu shouldn’t block the content (i.e. text, or some canvas type view like Keynote).

elements.text: powers the new light-weight edit menu. Use Edit menu interaction in contexts where you don’t need a preview, or where the menu shouldn’t block the content (i.e. text, or some canvas type view like Keynote).

messages.text:
<@U03JRQ81NEL> asked
> In iOS 15, compositional layout with orthogonal scrolling behaviour with a single section in non-full screen size also scrolls vertically, what is the correct way to prevent vertical scrolling for single horizontal section?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"In iOS 15, compositional layout with orthogonal scrolling behaviour with a single section in non-full screen size also scrolls vertically, what is the correct way to prevent vertical scrolling for single horizontal section?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If it is the outer (collection) view that is scrolling, you can set `alwaysBounceVertical = false` on it to prevent the scrolling. However if it is just a single section you may be better of not using an orthogonal section but just a horizontally scrolling collection view. This might be a great question to discuss in the labs later this week to find a solution that works best for you.

messages.text:
<@U03JRR4R3CY> asked
> Since setValue:forKey: on UIDevice is not longer supported to force orientation. Is there are step by step explanation of how to force landscape orientation for 1 UIViewController only?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Since setValue"},{"type":"emoji","name":"forKey"},{"type":"text","text":" on UIDevice is not longer supported to force orientation. Is there are step by step explanation of how to force landscape orientation for 1 UIViewController only?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You can call `+[UIViewController attemptRotationToDeviceOrientation]` and return an updated `UIInterfaceOrientationMask` from `-[UIViewController supportedInterfaceOrientations]`.

It’s also important to note that `setValue:forKey:` to access and modify internal state is never a supported way to do things. You might get lucky but you should really consider this as not being supported and should file feedback to request API for the feature you are trying to access.

elements.text: It’s also important to note that

Hey <@U03JRR4R3CY> we have also such a button and the same problem now. After the button press we support that the user can rotate back with a physical orientation change. It's not a nice solution in my opinion, but it seems to work to temporarily override supportedInterfaceOrientation, call attemptRotationToDeviceOrientation() and then reset supportedInterfaceOrientation to all normally allowed orientations again.

I started making a prototype here. Maybe it's useful for you too.

Photoshop has an SVG exporter, but it's only present on Intel builds of Photoshop.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Those are some great tools. It’s unfortunate that they aren’t working for you, though. I’d recommend reaching out to the developer of those apps for assistance with SVGs.

The design team likes to support Photoshop, XD, Sketch, and Keynote in their workflow as shown in the <https://developer.apple.com/design/resources/|Apple Design Resources>. There are a lot of other great vector editing tools on the Mac App Store, too.

In a pinch, you could even edit the SVG file manually since it is just XML and can be edited as plain text. I’ve personally done this for a few small changes when I didn’t yet have my usual go-to design tools installed.

messages.text:
<@U03JHTBKY59> asked
> The session mentioned NSWindow.collectionBehavior, but how will Stage Manager interact with NSWindow.level? More specifically, if I have a window in my app that I globally float above all other windows by setting the level to NSWindow.Level.screenSaver, will that window still appear in Stage Manager?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"The session mentioned NSWindow.collectionBehavior, but how will Stage Manager interact with NSWindow.level? More specifically, if I have a window in my app that I globally float above all other windows by setting the level to NSWindow.Level.screenSaver, will that window still appear in Stage Manager?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Window levels still work the same way in Stage Manager, in that they’ll impact the z-ordering of your window with respect to other windows on screen. Otherwise, its relationship to other windows in center stage (like whether it’s considered “floating” or “auxiliary”) is dictated by its collection behavior.

elements.text: Window levels still work the same way in Stage Manager, in that they’ll impact the z-ordering of your window with respect to other windows on screen. Otherwise, its relationship to other windows in center stage (like whether it’s considered “floating” or “auxiliary”) is dictated by its collection behavior.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thank you Jeff!

messages.text:
<@U03HMDFMVNK> asked
> If I have an app that's primarily written in AppKit, is there any way to use SwiftUI to define toolbar items from within an AppKit window? Or does the window itself need to be created by SwiftUI too for that to work?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"If I have an app that's primarily written in AppKit, is there any way to use SwiftUI to define toolbar items from within an AppKit window? Or does the window itself need to be created by SwiftUI too for that to work?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You can attach your own NSView hierarchies to NSToolbarItems. Within these, you can use the `NSHostingController` or `NSHostView` classes offered by SwiftUI to embed a SwiftUI view hierarchy in an AppKit view hierarchy.

elements.text: You can attach your own NSView hierarchies to NSToolbarItems. Within these, you can use the
classes offered by SwiftUI to embed a SwiftUI view hierarchy in an AppKit view hierarchy.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: It is correct that the SwiftUI `.toolbar()` modifier only works with windows that are created and managed by SwiftUI. But, as Chris said, you can bring SwiftUI content into your `NSToolbar` using a hosting view.

elements.text: It is correct that the SwiftUI
modifier only works with windows that are created and managed by SwiftUI. But, as Chris said, you can bring SwiftUI content into your

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Got it, thanks!

messages.text: Welcome to the UIFrameworks Q&A! For this activity, we’re looking forward to answering your questions about UIKit, AppKit, or Catalyst. Select the:heavy_plus_sign:icon from the lower left, and find the _Ask A Question_ workflow. Type in your question and it will be delivered directly to the team. We’ll answer as many questions as we can. While it’s unlikely we’ll be able to address every question, all your submissions are valuable; thank you for taking the time! :rocket:. Also don’t forget that you can request follow up in the UIFrameworks labs scheduled for Thursday and Friday.

<@U03JRN827HN> asked
> Is the new `UIHostingConfiguration` bound only to collection and table view cells? Or is this API designed to be used in other places where I might "inject" SwiftUI views in the middle of custom UIKit view hierarchies?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Is the new `UIHostingConfiguration` bound only to collection and table view cells? Or is this API designed to be used in other places where I might \"inject\" SwiftUI views in the middle of custom UIKit view hierarchies?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: UIHostingConfiguration is designed to be used with UICollectionView and UITableView cells. Watch the video “Use SwiftUI with UIKit” coming on Thursday later this week to learn more about it, and other ways to integrate SwiftUI into your UIKit app! <https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/10072>

attachments.fallback: Apple Developer: Use SwiftUI with UIKit - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
attachments.title: Use SwiftUI with UIKit - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
attachments.text: Learn how to take advantage of the power of SwiftUI in your UIKit app. Build custom UICollectionView and UITableView cells seamlessly...

elements.text: UIHostingConfiguration is designed to be used with UICollectionView and UITableView cells. Watch the video “Use SwiftUI with UIKit” coming on Thursday later this week to learn more about it, and other ways to integrate SwiftUI into your UIKit app!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thank you! So if I’m vending a mostly UIKit-based framework and I want my users to be able to customize/replace a part of the hierarchy with SwiftUI, embedding a child `UIHostingController` continues to be the most recommended way to support this? `UIHostingController` looked to be a _much_ better fit… :smile:

elements.text: Thank you! So if I’m vending a mostly UIKit-based framework and I want my users to be able to customize/replace a part of the hierarchy with SwiftUI, embedding a child
continues to be the most recommended way to support this?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: `UIHostingController` is the most general-purpose API to embed SwiftUI inside your UIKit app. Because it is a view controller, you can use it anywhere you can present or embed a view controller in UIKit, and all SwiftUI features are supported inside of it (including ones that require a connection to the view controller hierarchy in UIKit). UIHostingController also has some new features in iOS 16, so be sure to watch the “Use SwiftUI with UIKit” video to learn more about all of this later this week.

elements.text: is the most general-purpose API to embed SwiftUI inside your UIKit app. Because it is a view controller, you can use it anywhere you can present or embed a view controller in UIKit, and all SwiftUI features are supported inside of it (including ones that require a connection to the view controller hierarchy in UIKit). UIHostingController also has some new features in iOS 16, so be sure to watch the “Use SwiftUI with UIKit” video to learn more about all of this later this week.

<@U03JENQA0TB> asked
> Most SF Symbols appear to have transparent background colours. In AppKit, is there a way to get a white background colour so that coloured symbols look good on NSPopupButtons? Right now when the selection is hovering over an NSMenuItem with a coloured SF Symbol for the image, the symbol colour doesn't change to make it viewable. For example, if your accent colour is yellow and the NSMenuItem's image is yellow, it basically disappears from view (yellow on yellow).

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Most SF Symbols appear to have transparent background colours. In AppKit, is there a way to get a white background colour so that coloured symbols look good on NSPopupButtons? Right now when the selection is hovering over an NSMenuItem with a coloured SF Symbol for the image, the symbol colour doesn't change to make it viewable. For example, if your accent colour is yellow and the NSMenuItem's image is yellow, it basically disappears from view (yellow on yellow)."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
In general, we don’t alter color images for states like menu highlight, because your image might be something like an icon which doesn’t make sense to draw with a white foreground.

However, I think your SF Symbol example is a good case where we could be smarter, since we know more about the underlying symbol image. That would be an excellent enhancement request for us.

elements.text:
In general, we don’t alter color images for states like menu highlight, because your image might be something like an icon which doesn’t make sense to draw with a white foreground.

However, I think your SF Symbol example is a good case where we could be smarter, since we know more about the underlying symbol image. That would be an excellent enhancement request for us.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Excellent. I’ll submit feedback for it. When setting to multi-coloured SF Symbols, NSPopupButton just completely removes all the colours. But explicitly setting colours for them using pallet configuration does show the colours, but doesn’t invert or change the highlight state when traversing the popup button.

elements.text: Excellent. I’ll submit feedback for it. When setting to multi-coloured SF Symbols, NSPopupButton just completely removes all the colours. But explicitly setting colours for them using pallet configuration does show the colours, but doesn’t invert or change the highlight state when traversing the popup button.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: `NSMenu` does have a delegation mechanism that can tell you when an item has been highlighted. Try implementing `-menu:willHighlightItem:`, and altering the highlighted item. Since these are symbols, you could use `-[NSImage imageWithSymbolConfiguration:]` to get a new image with a different configuration, and set that to the highlighted item’s `image` property. Just be sure to restore the original image back to the previously-highlighted menu item and when the menu closes (`-menuDidClose:`).

<@U03JRQ81NEL> asked
> Is it possible to access swiftui environment/modifiers inside UIViewRepresentables?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Is it possible to access swiftui environment\/modifiers inside UIViewRepresentables?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Yes. The context passed to `make/updateUIView(context:)`
has an `environment` property you can read from.

<https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/uiviewrepresentable/makeuiview(context:)>
Or you can use `@Environment` in your representable struct.
Thanks :blush:

slackdump_thread_replies.text: So, I have a giant container UIView (inside a scrollview), containing a ton of small but overlapping CAShapeLayers. What’s the difference between turning on `shouldRasterize` on the container view vs. the individual shapelayers?

on the container view vs. the individual shapelayers?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I would guess that rasterizing the container view would be most performant, because scrolling would only be moving the one rasterized bitmap, rather than having to recomposite multiple bitmaps. But you'll really have to try this out to see if it works for you.

elements.text: I would guess that rasterizing the container view would be most performant, because scrolling would only be moving the one rasterized bitmap, rather than having to recomposite multiple bitmaps. But you'll really have to try this out to see if it works for you.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Another thing you can try is setting `drawsAsynchronously = true` on the shape layers. This will allow the layers to perform the actual drawing on background threads, which may be faster, but since it won't be synchronized with the main loop, you might "see" the strokes being drawn independent of the current CA transaction.

elements.text: Another thing you can try is setting

on the shape layers. This will allow the layers to perform the actual drawing on background threads, which may be faster, but since it won't be synchronized with the main loop, you might "see" the strokes being drawn independent of the current CA transaction.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I _think_ setting shouldRasterize on only the container view will rasterize all of the overlapping CAShapeLayers into one bitmap. Setting shouldRasterize on the only the individual CAShapeLayers will rasterize each bezier path separately, and CA will not cache the composition of them all together. I’m not sure which of these is more or less performant, and the answer might depend on your implementation.

I’m not sure which of these is more or less performant, and the answer might depend on your implementation.

E.g. turn it off for large shapes, turn it on for small shapes. You may even have to figure out which shapes could be combined in a rasterization e.g. by putting them in a common layer and setting the flag there.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: CALayers (including CAShapeLayer) are rendered with Metal in another process (as you’ve observed), so that’s why you’re seeing that process get saturated, not your own.

elements.text: CALayers (including CAShapeLayer) are rendered with Metal in another process (as you’ve observed), so that’s why you’re seeing that process get saturated, not your own.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
> Say I have a 10000pt height container view with two tiny shape layers on top-left and bottom-right, does setting shouldRasterize on the container view create a giant bitmap that will kill the app due to memory pressure?
I think the memory pressure would be in another process, not your app (since CAShapeLayer is rendered out of process), but in general I think this would cause memory pressure on the system. So I don’t think you want to use `shouldRasterize` on large layers.

<@U03HZ81AHCN> asked
> Hi, how can I change some properties of NSWindow (such as the titlebar color) when using Catalyst?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Hi, how can I change some properties of NSWindow (such as the titlebar color) when using Catalyst?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Use the `UITitlebarTitleVisibilityHidden` option on `UITitlebar.titleVisibility` to disable the titlebar material, window title, and its toolbar. You can then provide your own view underneath. The window’s safe area insets still apply and the area beyond those insets remain draggable. Note that the `UITitlebar` cannot have an `NSToolbar` in order for this to work.

messages.text:
<@U03J22P9WKH> asked
> I would like to allow users to configure command keys for menus in my app. However, I have not found a way to change the command keys (or add / remove  menus) after the initial builder phase occurs (via the AppDelegate). As a test, I built my menus, and then used a Dispatch after to remove the View menu after 4 seconds. I'm reusing the same builder that was passed in. However, nothing happens. Is the expected? Is there a way to update the command keys after launch?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"I would like to allow users to configure command keys for menus in my app. However, I have not found a way to change the command keys (or add \/ remove  menus) after the initial builder phase occurs (via the AppDelegate). As a test, I built my menus, and then used a Dispatch after to remove the View menu after 4 seconds. I'm reusing the same builder that was passed in. However, nothing happens. Is the expected? Is there a way to update the command keys after launch?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Updating the main menu needs to happen synchronously in the `-buildMenuWithBuilder:` method. If you want to update the main menu later, you need to call UIMenuSystem.main.setNeedsRebuild(), and that’ll call buildMenuWithBuilder again (lazily).

elements.text: Updating the main menu needs to happen synchronously in the
method. If you want to update the main menu later, you need to call UIMenuSystem.main.setNeedsRebuild(), and that’ll call buildMenuWithBuilder again (lazily).

slackdump_thread_replies.text: awesome!

Also note that on macOS / Catalyst, it is best to avoid a dynamically changing menu bar structure.
All items should be in the same location at all times, so they're easy to discover and their location is easy to remember.
Instead of adding/removing items, use validation to disable items when they are not applicable.

elements.text:

slackdump_thread_replies.text: This is a very great question. Right now it is not generally possible to have code running indefinitely while an app is in the background. We have special endpoints for things like voip but do not support generic background processes. I’d suggest filing feedback and also reaching out to evangelism about potential use cases that you might have for this.

elements.text: This is a very great question. Right now it is not generally possible to have code running indefinitely while an app is in the background. We have special endpoints for things like voip but do not support generic background processes. I’d suggest filing feedback and also reaching out to evangelism about potential use cases that you might have for this.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Also a disclaimer: this question has legal implications since you are mentioning aviation which is explicitly mentioned in the iPadOS license agreement under 7.5. So the answer above is purely based on the technical feasibility as we can not give you legal advice here.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Multipeer is odd cause there's no real “host” and “client”…. You could manage a host using communicated meta data though.

I also think you disconnect from the network when the app gets backgrounded too…

You might want to take a look at CoreBluetooth, as it explicitly allows an app to continue scanning for peripherals while backgrounded. See [this doc](<https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/NetworkingInternetWeb/Conceptual/CoreBluetooth_concepts/CoreBluetoothBackgroundProcessingForIOSApps/PerformingTasksWhileYourAppIsInTheBackground.html|https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/NetworkingInternetWeb/Concep[…]orIOSApps/PerformingTasksWhileYourAppIsInTheBackground.html>)

This is _not_ a recommendation for your application. Please contact developer relations to explore legal and other implications.

<@U03J1UAEU4B> asked
> Are there any particular reasons (that you can reveal) for why there’s no general UIHostingView, only UIHostingController, whereas AppKit has NSHostingView available?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Are there any particular reasons (that you can reveal) for why there\u2019s no general UIHostingView, only UIHostingController, whereas AppKit has NSHostingView available?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: This is intentional, because our architecture relies on a UIView being a part of a view controller hierarchy (and thus, being "owned" by a view controller). Think of things like modal presentations, responder chain, etc.

elements.text: This is intentional, because our architecture relies on a UIView being a part of a view controller hierarchy (and thus, being "owned" by a view controller). Think of things like modal presentations, responder chain, etc.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: This is partially touched on in Use SwiftUI with UIKit as well! <https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/10072>

Hi everyone! Welcome to the <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10070/|Build a Desktop Class App> Watch Party! :confetti_ball: We’re so happy to have you all here! My name is Ian and I’m a Screening Engineer for our UIFrameworks. In this hour, we invite everyone to watch Build a Desktop Class App together! Queue up the video and get ready to hit play at 10:05 PDT. :clock10:

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Similarly, if I change the title/image, do they update if already visible?

elements.text: Similarly, if I change the title/image, do they update if already visible?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: No, it won't. The only way to update a visible menu is using `UIContextMenuInteraction.updateVisibleMenu()` if you're using `UIContextMenuInteraction` directly, or by setting the button's `menu` property to a new value if you're using a `UIButton`. Menus are copied when consumed by the system, so any instance you may be holding onto is no longer directly connected to what's visible.

messages.text:
Hi everyone! Welcome to the Bring your iOS app to the Mac Watch Party! It’s fantastic to have you all here! My name is Jason and I’m the manager for Mac Catalyst. In this hour, we invite everyone to watch Bring your iOS app to the Mac together! Queue up the video and get ready to hit play at 1:05 PDT.

In the meantime, I’m so excited to introduce you to the speaker, Owen. In addition to Owen, we’re joined here by almost the entire Mac Catalyst team, ready to answer your questions!

There’s a lot of us here, so we’re going to do our best to keep things organized. As the video progresses, I’ll be creating threads associated with each section of the talk, where everyone can chat and ask questions.

When the video finishes, we’ll have some time left over for additional targeted Q&A, which I’ll explain when we get there. So for the next few minutes, grab your popcorn, get comfortable, and get ready to hit that play button! :popcorn:

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"macOS ExtensionKit question. Does an extension have to be delivered within an app bundle? Is it possible to build a standalone `.appex` and have it be discoverable by an hosting application?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: It is not possible to deliver an extension outside of an app bundle. Extensions must be contained in an app bundle in the `Extensions` directory.

Ah hello! Thanks for your help yesterday!

Would be awesome to not need to create wrapper apps to deliver extension-only payloads. I’ll file a bug report.

elements.text:
Ah hello! Thanks for your help yesterday!

Would be awesome to not need to create wrapper apps to deliver extension-only payloads. I’ll file a bug report.

Will all of ExtensionKit’s capabilities be available to apps delivered outside the App Store using Developer ID?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Happy to help.
Yes ExtensionKit’s capabilities are supported apps delivered outside of the App Store. The host app and the extension must be code signed and the extension must be sandboxed.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You can achieve endless scrolling by essentially adding and removing sections while scrolling and making sure to adjust the content offset when doing so. `UIScrollView` (and thus `UICollectionView`) will keep its inertia and make it look seamless. If you have specific use cases this might be a great thing to discuss in a 1on1 lab.

messages.text:
<@U03JU8F54C8> asked
> iOS 16 offers a great new API addition in the way of UIHostingConfiguration for rendering SwiftUI views in List CollectionView cells, however we’d love to support this type of interop on iOS 15 too.  When using UIHostingControllers in UICollectionView list cells, is there any specific considerations that should be taken into account in addition to managing cell reuse issues?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"iOS 16 offers a great new API addition in the way of UIHostingConfiguration for rendering SwiftUI views in List CollectionView cells, however we\u2019d love to support this type of interop on iOS 15 too. \u2028When using UIHostingControllers in UICollectionView list cells, is there any specific considerations that should be taken into account in addition to managing cell reuse issues?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Unfortunately there isn’t an officially supported way to use SwiftUI inside of UIKit cells prior to iOS 16. Embedding a UIHostingController inside of cells is not recommended.

elements.text: Unfortunately there isn’t an officially supported way to use SwiftUI inside of UIKit cells prior to iOS 16. Embedding a UIHostingController inside of cells is not recommended.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Just to be clear, it's not recommended due to performance issues, right?

elements.text: Just to be clear, it's not recommended due to performance issues, right?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: <@U03HW7U6QF3> This is great to know, thank you! Is there any further light you can shed on why? As Lior comments, I am guessing due to performance overhead or reuse pitfalls?

elements.text: This is great to know, thank you! Is there any further light you can shed on why? As Lior comments, I am guessing due to performance overhead or reuse pitfalls?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: i love this new feature!!!!

While performance is certainly a concern, the main issue is really around the nature of needing to embed a view controller (the UIHostingController) in each cell. Generally speaking, putting view controllers inside cells is discouraged in UIKit. This is because of how cell reuse works, as well as the way information propagates through the view controller and view hierarchy in UIKit. So using UIHostingController in cells creates problems and can result in some surprising bugs. (A common example we’ve seen are issues with safe area information propagating into SwiftUI.) These are all things that the new UIHostingConfiguration API addresses!

elements.text: While performance is certainly a concern, the main issue is really around the nature of needing to embed a view controller (the UIHostingController) in each cell. Generally speaking, putting view controllers inside cells is discouraged in UIKit. This is because of how cell reuse works, as well as the way information propagates through the view controller and view hierarchy in UIKit. So using UIHostingController in cells creates problems and can result in some surprising bugs. (A common example we’ve seen are issues with safe area information propagating into SwiftUI.) These are all things that the new UIHostingConfiguration API addresses!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: TIL
Makes complete sense. So glad to see the new UIHostingConfiguration API and we'll be eager to adopt it once our minimum version is 16! Thanks to you and team for your hard work.

elements.text: Makes complete sense. So glad to see the new UIHostingConfiguration API and we'll be eager to adopt it once our minimum version is 16! Thanks to you and team for your hard work.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Despite that advice not to use UIHostingController in cells, provided that you are using the supported UIHostingConfiguration API starting with iOS 16, if you are able to get something working with UIHostingController on previous iOS versions and you have tested it well enough yourself that you know it works and meets your needs, you can _probably_ get away with that because UIKit & SwiftUI aren’t changing anymore on those older iOS versions. And since you’re using UIHostingConfiguration going forward, you won’t run into any new issues with the unsupported UIHostingController implementation in the future. But again, this is not officially supported, so you are on your own, and you need to thoroughly test to make sure you can find an implementation that works well enough.

elements.text: Despite that advice not to use UIHostingController in cells, provided that you are using the supported UIHostingConfiguration API starting with iOS 16, if you are able to get something working with UIHostingController on previous iOS versions and you have tested it well enough yourself that you know it works and meets your needs, you can

get away with that because UIKit & SwiftUI aren’t changing anymore on those older iOS versions. And since you’re using UIHostingConfiguration going forward, you won’t run into any new issues with the unsupported UIHostingController implementation in the future. But again, this is not officially supported, so you are on your own, and you need to thoroughly test to make sure you can find an implementation that works well enough.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: <@U03HW7U6QF3> would these concerns also apply to general usage of UIHostingControllers for leaf node views, like buttons? VC pattern would generally not be used there in pure UIKit world, and UIHostingControllers force us into it. Are there perf concerns? Is leaf node SwiftUI in UIKit discouraged, or is it okay if we properly add the VCs in the VC hierarchy?

elements.text: would these concerns also apply to general usage of UIHostingControllers for leaf node views, like buttons? VC pattern would generally not be used there in pure UIKit world, and UIHostingControllers force us into it. Are there perf concerns? Is leaf node SwiftUI in UIKit discouraged, or is it okay if we properly add the VCs in the VC hierarchy?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Not really, the specific issues mentioned above are really about having view controllers inside cells (inside of a UIScrollView), due to cell reuse and scrolling performance.

elements.text: Not really, the specific issues mentioned above are really about having view controllers inside cells (inside of a UIScrollView), due to cell reuse and scrolling performance.

messages.text:
<@U03J4DRK4SY> asked
> With the new self-sizing cells, is there a way to run an animation alongside a cell resize animation (or at least, adding a custom completion handler to the system-provided resize animation)?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"With the new self-sizing cells, is there a way to run an animation alongside a cell resize animation (or at least, adding a custom completion handler to the system-provided resize animation)?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
With the new `selfSizingInvalidation` feature (aka “self-resizing cells”), when a cell is resized with animation, the cell will also receive a full layout pass as part of the same animation. This means that any layout changes to subviews inside the cell’s `contentView` will also animate by default alongside the resizing of the cell itself.

There isn’t an explicit way to manually attach animations to that resize animation when it’s initiated directly by a cell via `invalidateIntrinsicContentSize` — do you have something specific in mind you’re trying to do?

elements.text: feature (aka “self-resizing cells”), when a cell is resized with animation, the cell will also receive a full layout pass as part of the same animation. This means that any layout changes to subviews inside the cell’s

will also animate by default alongside the resizing of the cell itself.

There isn’t an explicit way to manually attach animations to that resize animation when it’s initiated directly by a cell via
— do you have something specific in mind you’re trying to do?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You can of course continue to use the `apply` method on diffable data source (re-applying the current snapshot), or `performBatchUpdates` on the collection/table view directly if you are not using a diffable data source, to resize visible cells as you would prior to iOS 16. And both of those APIs do provide a completion handler you can use.

, when you want the cell to size-to-fit the text view as more text is added!

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
> Relatedly, the text view is in a stack view and the cell isn’t automatically detecting the change when isHidden is changed on the text view (which should, AIUI, cause the stack view to change its internal constraints which should count as an auto layout change). I have to call invalidateIntrinsicContentSize myself to get the size to update. Could that be something on my end, or is it more likely a framework bug?
If you have an easy place to call `invalidateIntrinsicContentSize`  yourself, that’s actually the best option in general combined with the default `selfSizingInvalidation = .enabled` . The `.enabledIncludingConstraints` mode can be more expensive, as it requires checking for size changes on any Auto Layout constraint changes.

But based on your description this does sound like something that is supposed to work automatically when you have set `.enabledIncludingConstraints` , so if you don’t see any obvious issues on your end, it would be great if you could submit a Feedback report with a small sample project attached for us to take a look at! <https://feedbackassistant.apple.com>

elements.text: “…when a cell is resized with animation, the cell will also receive a full layout pass as part of the same animation.”  Is this true for updates via performBatchUpdates as well?  My recollection is that there were issues around the cell view instance getting swapped out which would end up killing the animation within the cell. slackdump_thread_replies.text:
> My recollection is that there were issues around the cell view instance getting swapped out which would end up killing the animation within the cell. Are cell views always preserved across empty batch updates, or am I misremembering?
For empty batch updates, as well as the new iOS 16 self-sizing invalidation feature, the existing cells won’t be replaced or reused. Only when using the `reload` API to reload an item/section will the cell get replaced with a new one.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"My recollection is that there were issues around the cell view instance getting swapped out which would end up killing the animation within the cell. Are cell views always preserved across empty batch updates, or am I misremembering?"}]}

elements.text: For empty batch updates, as well as the new iOS 16 self-sizing invalidation feature, the existing cells won’t be replaced or reused. Only when using the
API to reload an item/section will the cell get replaced with a new one.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks Tyler!
(Don’t forget about the `reconfigure` API introduced in iOS 15 to update cells without replacing them, too!)

elements.text: API introduced in iOS 15 to update cells without replacing them, too!)

Thank you so much for joining us for this Q&A! We’ve had a ton of fun and I hope you did too! :partying_face:

Even though this was the last general Q&A digital lounge for UI Frameworks, you can still get a hold of our engineers in one of the upcoming labs Thursday and Friday!
Additionally, tomorrow we will be hosting a Q&A specific to using *UIKit and AppKit with SwiftUI* together in the same app tomorrow at *8 AM PDT*. Two related videos will also become available: *<https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10072/|Use SwiftUI with UIKit>* and *<https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10075/|Use SwiftUI with AppKit>*. I’m super excited about it and hoping to see you and your questions tomorrow!

Thank you and have a great evening! :wwdc22: :gratitude-thank-you:

messages.text: <@U03J7BQ7P9N> added a workflow to this channel: *UIFrameworks - Ask a Question*.

Welcome to the SwiftUI/UIKit/AppKit Q&A! We have many Apple engineers here from all of these frameworks eager to answer your questions.

In this Q&A, we’re specifically focusing on questions about using SwiftUI together with UIKit and AppKit.

To ask a question, click the:heavy_plus_sign:icon on the lower left, and choose the “_Ask a question”_ workflow. Type your question and submit it. We’ll answer as many questions as we can, but if we don’t get to yours, rest assured that we do read every question and we truly appreciate you taking the time to ask yours!

Let’s get started! :rocket:

messages.text:
<@U03J0GP5L6R> asked
> Hello, should we approach SwiftUI views as data models for real views? Where should we place data formatting logic? If SwiftUI view is a data model we can data formatting logic there? How can we test our data formatting logic in this case?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Hello, should we approach SwiftUI views as data models for real views? Where should we place data formatting logic? If SwiftUI view is a data model we can data formatting logic there? How can we test our data formatting logic in this case?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The most convenient way to unit test your data formatting logic (like a Foundation FormatStyle) will be to factor the formatter out and assert against the String it produces

elements.text: The most convenient way to unit test your data formatting logic (like a Foundation FormatStyle) will be to factor the formatter out and assert against the String it produces

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I generally wouldn't consider a SwiftUI view to be a data model

elements.text: I generally wouldn't consider a SwiftUI view to be a data model

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Factoring out the formatter might take the form of lifting into a model or view model

elements.text: Factoring out the formatter might take the form of lifting into a model or view model

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Or it might just take the form of specifying it in a computed property on the View and running the assertion against that

elements.text: Or it might just take the form of specifying it in a computed property on the View and running the assertion against that

slackdump_thread_replies.text: So, we can use property testing to assert data formatting directly inside SwiftUI Views. Is it good practice? How do you deal with this problem at Apple in big projects?

elements.text: So, we can use property testing to assert data formatting directly inside SwiftUI Views. Is it good practice? How do you deal with this problem at Apple in big projects?

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Unit testing is a bit of an art and so I wouldn't say it's a necessarily a good or bad practice to assert directly against the SwiftUI view.

I think the concerns are more pragmatic: how easy is it to assert against the SwiftUI view vs against a model. Does one way or the other require extra boilerplate? Does one way or the other lead to fewer false negatives?

<@U03HPFD1GG7> asked
> Does this new APIs are backward comaptible with UIKit project or just only iOS 16?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Does this new APIs are backward comaptible with UIKit project or just only iOS 16?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: In general all APIs that are introduced in new versions of our operating systems always require those versions to be used. However you can conditionalize your code to only use those new features when running on that OS and have your app back deploy to old versions without those features.

elements.text: In general all APIs that are introduced in new versions of our operating systems always require those versions to be used. However you can conditionalize your code to only use those new features when running on that OS and have your app back deploy to old versions without those features.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Ok got it, but it might double the implementation and maintenance

elements.text: Ok got it, but it might double the implementation and maintenance

slackdump_thread_replies.text: That, unfortunately, is a technical limitation. These features are implemented in frameworks that are shipping with the OS and that are heavily integrated with the OS, so they require the new OS to work. In a lot of cases you can just add the new features when running on the new OS and just do nothing on older versions, in which case it is enough to just check the current version you are running at run time before calling out to the new APIs.

In a lot of cases you can just add the new features when running on the new OS and just do nothing on older versions, in which case it is enough to just check the current version you are running at run time before calling out to the new APIs.

messages.text:
<@U03JN2CBSEM> asked
> What’s the naming convention you’d recommend using for a SwiftUI view - with or without `View` suffix? I think I’ve seen both in Apple examples.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"What\u2019s the naming convention you\u2019d recommend using for a SwiftUI view - with or without `View` suffix? I think I\u2019ve seen both in Apple examples."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
A good rule of thumb is that if the name we are picking has a clear visual representation, say `Text`, `Image`, `Toggle`, we omit the view suffix.

In cases like `ProgressView` where `Progress` really would feel more like the data itself than its visual representation we add the `View` suffix. Specifically in the case of `Progress` we would clash with `Foundation.Progress` which will require developer to always fully qualify the type name which is not ideal.

> Once again, here goes the question about SwiftUI views in Table/Collection cell. :grin:
> If we'd like to tinker with our own UIHostingConfiguration to support older OS versions, what would be the recommended way to update cell's height when used with DiffableDataSource?
> Currently, the most common scenario I see is a pair of 
> tableView.beginUpdates()
> tableView.endUpdates()
> 
> It would be nice to recap on our available options.

elements.Raw:
{"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Once again, here goes the question about SwiftUI views in Table/Collection cell. "},{"type":"emoji","name":"grin"},{"type":"text","text":"
If we'd like to tinker with our own UIHostingConfiguration to support older OS versions, what would be the recommended way to update cell's height when used with DiffableDataSource?
Currently, the most common scenario I see is a pair of 
tableView.beginUpdates()
tableView.endUpdates()

It would be nice to recap on our available options."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
On iOS 15 and earlier, you request an update to the size of self-sizing cells in UICollectionView and UITableView by:
• If using diffable data source, re-applying the diffable data source’s current snapshot with `animatingDifferences: true`
• If not using diffable data source, performing empty batch updates on the collection or table view directly (that’s the same as the begin/end updates you mentioned)

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hi there! This looks like a potentially issue in CoreAnimation. If you haven't already, can you file a feedback with the entire crash log?

elements.text: Hi there! This looks like a potentially issue in CoreAnimation. If you haven't already, can you file a feedback with the entire crash log?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Sure thing. Thanks! :slightly_smiling_face:
Thank you!

Apps generally have around 5 seconds to stop processing when they’re backgrounded. If an app is still ‘alive’ and doing things at that point, it will be terminated to preserve system responsiveness.

In this 5 seconds, we usually reconfigure your apps interface multiple times (rotating, switching to light/dark mode etc.) to take screenshots to use in the application switcher UI.

What might be happening here is that your app is taking a long time to lay out for these screenshots. It may be finishing in just _under_ five seconds - then this system code (which frees up memory used by CA that’s not necessary while your app has nothing on screen) runs - and during that we hit the timeout.

If your crash trace has a “termination reason” that mentions “watchdog” that’s an indication that this might be happening.

messages.text:
<@U03HMDKEWJK> asked
> I was wondering if we can use the SwiftUI View protocol with the new 'any' keyword? And if it'll be helpful or a good solution in some example use-case?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"I was wondering if we can use the SwiftUI View protocol with the new 'any' keyword? And if it'll be helpful or a good solution in some example use-case?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
`any View` does not itself conform to `View`, so is not a replacement for `AnyView` today. Also `any View` is only defining an existential container that you can use in a type signature but you can’t instantiate that type.

There might be use cases for using `any View` to store that into collection, for example: `[any View]`.  But most of the time, if you’re in the situation where you think you need `[AnyView]` or `[any View]`, what you should likely do is invert the view dependency flow and have `[AnyDataModel]` or `[any DataModel]`  instead, then create your views based on the type of data provided at runtime.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Here is the video

Hi Pavan, there are a few different strategies you can take here, depending on how you’re updating your cells. What you’ll want to do is to apply a content offset to the scroll view that is the _inverse_ of the increase in the size from cells above the currently visible area. This would need to be performed synchronously, however. The details here depend on the specifics of your layout definition, though.

Another alternative is to use `.estimated` for your item definitions, Then, if their size changes, UICollectionView will automatically adjust the content offset to preserve the semantic scroll position.

messages.text:
<@U03JMMN8659> asked
> Using ShareLink in SwiftUI and Transferable, we will now be able to share custom types between users. How does this compare to sharing Core Data entities using a .shared CloudKit database? As I understand, the main difference is that sharing using Transferable copies the item from User A and pastes it for User B, so in the end there will be 2 instances of this item, with no synchronization. Any subsequent changes to any of the items will remain local for that user. In contrast, sharing using .shared CloudKit database means a single entity will be synchronized for both users. Am I on the right track? Are there some other key differences to be aware of?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Using ShareLink in SwiftUI and Transferable, we will now be able to share custom types between users. How does this compare to sharing Core Data entities using a .shared CloudKit database? As I understand, the main difference is that sharing using Transferable copies the item from User A and pastes it for User B, so in the end there will be 2 instances of this item, with no synchronization. Any subsequent changes to any of the items will remain local for that user. In contrast, sharing using .shared CloudKit database means a single entity will be synchronized for both users. Am I on the right track? Are there some other key differences to be aware of?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hi Jan!

> How does this compare to sharing Core Data entities using a .shared CloudKit database?
There is a difference: `ShareLink` is used for sharing here and now, not for persistent storage. Core Data is a database–and its intended use is for storing items on the disk.

> As I understand, the main difference is that sharing using Transferable copies the item from User A and pastes it for User B
It depends on which transport APIs we are using. For example, Drag and Drop allows sharing items within a single process or between different processes. Copy/paste works similarly.

If we are using `FileRepresentation`, we can specify the `allowAccessingOriginalFile` parameter for `SentTransferredFiles` and tell the system if should make the copy, or not.

`Transferable` doesn’t provide any synchronization, just passes around data.

messages.text:
<@U03JRP87THN> asked
> Hi there! What's the recommended way to repeatedly fetch data in a SwiftUI app, (so that we don't push updates from a different thread)?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Hi there! What's the recommended way to repeatedly fetch data in a SwiftUI app, (so that we don't push updates from a different thread)?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
In general, I would suggest to factor out the logic that fetches the data into its own type. You always want to execute this kind of side effect not on the main thread and the hop back onto the main thread to set the data on the model.

Swift’s actors are a great tool to encapsulate this kind of logic. So for example you could the model that is offered to the view be an `ObservableObject` that is bound to the main actor, and have a separate actor (hence running on a separate thread) that takes care of the fetching and report back new data to your observable object.

that is bound to the main actor, and have a separate actor (hence running on a separate thread) that takes care of the fetching and report back new data to your observable object.

I think conformance to ObservableObject is not the issue here. What you want is for your function to be wrapped in the Main actor, so updates to UI are pushed on the main thread: @MainActor func getData() {}

elements.text: I think conformance to ObservableObject is not the issue here. What you want is for your function to be wrapped in the Main actor, so updates to UI are pushed on the main thread: @MainActor func getData() {}

messages.text:
<@U03JB2UUT46> asked
> Would you use SwiftUI or UIKit to implement a list that can change layout between a table and grid layouts? I currently have a UICollectionView with different layouts but I can't animate between the layout change.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Would you use SwiftUI or UIKit to implement a list that can change layout between a table and grid layouts? I currently have a UICollectionView with different layouts but I can't animate between the layout change."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: ~…what’s your iOS target version~ :smiling_imp:

As always we recommend using the tool that is best for the job. UICollectionView does support animating layout changes via `setLayout:animated:` so there is no need to rewrite this in SwiftUI. If there are specific things you want to achieve that can only be achieved in SwiftUI, then of course converting it to that is a very valid option.

messages.text:
<@U03J0GP5L6R> asked
> Assume that I keep the whole app state in the state object in my app struct? This way I can make sure that all the views are in a consistent state and have a single source of truth. How can I tune performance because in this case, SwiftUI starts diffing the whole app view hierarchy on every single change of the app state?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Assume that I keep the whole app state in the state object in my app struct? This way I can make sure that all the views are in a consistent state and have a single source of truth. How can I tune performance because in this case, SwiftUI starts diffing the whole app view hierarchy on every single change of the app state?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
You’re completely right that with a single observable object, you’ll end up invalidating large parts of your view hierarchy whenever a change occurs. Invalidating even large amounts of the SwiftUI view hierarchy should be an inexpensive operation, as view descriptions are rather lightweight, but if you are running into performance issues here, there are a few things you can do to help. The first recommendation I have is to split out some of the values which are only relevant to a certain subset of views into their own observable object. This is likely going to get you the most performance win of any of these suggestions, but if you don’t want to make that architectural change, there are still some things you can do:

• Avoid marking non-published values of your `ObservableObject` published
• (Assuming you’re using `EnvironmentObject` to make sure your single `StateObject` can be accessed throughout your view hierarchy) ensuring you only declare dependencies on the `EnvironmentObject` in places it’s needed
• And if you still need to optimize further, writing a custom `objectWillChange` implementation for your `StateObject`s which only does invalidation when changes that should actually affect the UI occur (in cases, for example, where published values have multiple different representations that should display in the same manner).

The user should be able to predict the outcome of each shortcut. If the selection focus changes which menu item is invoked, that would be confusing.

> I am new to SwiftUI, what is the best way to Switch between Views? For example, depending on the condition of a @State variable how can I switch between a HomeView, SignInView and SignUpView?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"I am new to SwiftUI, what is the best way to Switch between Views? For example, depending on the condition of a @State variable how can I switch between a HomeView, SignInView and SignUpView?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
I’ve personally done this before with a parent “container” view, an `enum` to represent the different possible views, and an `@State`  var that I use in a `switch` statement to swap out views. I have `@Binding` vars in all my child views so they can programatically change what’s shown in the parent.

However, with programatic navigation in `NavigationStack` that’d probably be the preferred way to do this, check out the <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10054/|SwiftUI cookbook for navigation >session by <@U03HW7P0HQR> for more

attachments.text: The recipe for a great app begins with a clear and robust navigation structure. Join the SwiftUI team in our proverbial coding kitchen...

messages.text:
<@U03J20KFJG3> asked
> SwiftUI: When using Self._printChanges() in the body of Views, what should we pay close attention to? Is @Self printed often harmful? What are the numbers @44 we see when using FetchRequest in the View.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"SwiftUI: When using Self._printChanges() in the body of Views, what should we pay close attention to? Is @Self printed often harmful? What are the numbers @44 we see when using FetchRequest in the View."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
`@Self` self is not inherently harmful. The purpose of `Self._printChanges()` is not to indicate that something is wrong but rather as a tool to match your expectation with what is happening at runtime.

What you want to be on the look out for is that you don’t do unnecessary invalidation which might cause performance issue.

If you see `@` followed by any number it means that we couldn’t find the field (property) name, so printed the byte offset of the swift view struct field instead.

I'm seeing lots of @Self printed when a View has an EnvironmentObject dependency (a Core Data object), and the object publishes a change. For example, a List of Core Data objects (owned) related to the EnvironmentObject (owner). If I update an owned object from the List, the relationship between the owner and the owned is updated, the owner EnvironmentObject publishes an update. This break the animation that should be displayed when updating the owned item in the List.

messages.text:
<@U03J2125SNP> asked
> Hi ! I’m still having an issue with generic view models in SwiftUI. I’m having trouble to understand what should I choose between `@ObservableObject` or `@StateObject` when injecting a generic view model into a SwiftUI view.
> 
> I’m commonly doing this:
> ```swift
> protocol ViewModelProtocol { }
> 
> struct MyView<ViewModel: ViewModelProtocol>: View {
>     @ObservedObject var viewModel: ViewModel
> }
> 
> let myViewModel = MyViewModel()
> let myView = MyView(viewModel: myViewModel)
> ```
> 
> In this case, the `viewModel` property should be `@StateObject` or `@ObservableObject` ?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I may add some precision to my code example. The `ViewModelProtocol` conforms to `ObservableObject`. And `MyViewModel` should be a `class` conforming to `ViewModelProtocol`

This particular example should be `@ObservedObject` <https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/10072>. There are a few nuances that are explained in this year's _Use SwiftUI with UIKit_ and last year's _Data Essentials_ sessions. With `@StateObject` , `MyView` would _own_ the model, and is at liberty to make a copy of it when initialized. That means that the `myViewModel` variable would become "disconnected" from the `@StateObject` .

elements.text: . There are a few nuances that are explained in this year's
the model, and is at liberty to make a copy of it when initialized. That means that the

slackdump_thread_replies.text: <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2020/10040|Data Essentials in SwiftUI>

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks for the quick reply ! What is a common case where `@StateObject` should be useful ? I feel like when I’m using it, I can’t mock any data because the model can’t be injected so it makes unit test or screenshots automation harder

If your view wants to own an ObservableObject view model, and the lifetime of that object should match the lifetime of the identity of the view, you should use StateObject.

You can initialize a StateObject with an external value using this code in your initializer:
```_viewModel = StateObject(wrappedValue: existingModel)```
Note that the value passed to that initializer is accessed once and can't change over time.

You can initialize a StateObject with an external value using this code in your initializer:

elements.text: Note that the value passed to that initializer is accessed once and can't change over time.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Thank you. It makes sense. With your solution, `@StateObject` allows me to mock the data passed to the view (example: if the view displays a list of books, I can pass the mocked book list to the view initializer and then instantiate the `StateObject`). But it does not allow me to mock the state of the view (example : if the view model controls wether or not the view is in editing mode)

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Is there any difference between `if #available`  and `@available` ?

Also note that Xcode will see that you are targeting an older version and will offer to put that check for you automatically. Either as `if #available`, or prefix your entire function or struct with `@available(iOS 16.0, *)`

elements.text: Also note that Xcode will see that you are targeting an older version and will offer to put that check for you automatically. Either as

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thank you!

`@available` is used to annotate your declarations to mark them as requiring a newer iOS version. For example, if you have a method that takes in an object/struct only available on iOS 16, then you need to annotate the method as `@available(iOS 16, *)`

elements.text: is used to annotate your declarations to mark them as requiring a newer iOS version. For example, if you have a method that takes in an object/struct only available on iOS 16, then you need to annotate the method as

slackdump_thread_replies.text: `#available` is a runtime check to be used in a condition. `@available` is an annotation for a method that makes that method unavailable. If your iOS 16 only code is run in a method that is only available in iOS 16 then the compiler won’t complain. So you can use a mixture of both.

elements.text: is a runtime check to be used in a condition.

is an annotation for a method that makes that method unavailable. If your iOS 16 only code is run in a method that is only available in iOS 16 then the compiler won’t complain. So you can use a mixture of both.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thank you!

Right, the compiler will then complain if you try to call that method on an older iOS version. Frameworks like UIKit and SwiftUI use this to prevent new API introduced in iOS 16 from being called on iOS 15, for example.

messages.text:
<@U03JEKM4LFK> asked
> Hi, is there any recommended way of making controls inside a SwiftUI’s `Form` look more native on macOS in an app made with Catalyst? Would I have to have an AppKit bundle/plugin that renders those SwiftUI views?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Hi, is there any recommended way of making controls inside a SwiftUI\u2019s `Form` look more native on macOS in an app made with Catalyst? Would I have to have an AppKit bundle\/plugin that renders those SwiftUI views?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
To enable macOS-native UI in your Catalyst app, go to your target's settings: General → Deployment Info → Mac Catalyst Interface, and switch from "Scaled to Match iPad" to "Optimize for Mac".

Controls in SwiftUI will automatically adapt to be more Mac-like in that mode. Also check out the new Form styles, to have the controls arranged in a traditional Mac columnar layout.

elements.text:
To enable macOS-native UI in your Catalyst app, go to your target's settings: General → Deployment Info → Mac Catalyst Interface, and switch from "Scaled to Match iPad" to "Optimize for Mac".

Controls in SwiftUI will automatically adapt to be more Mac-like in that mode. Also check out the new Form styles, to have the controls arranged in a traditional Mac columnar layout.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: From what I understand, this will put Mac controls into the iOS style Form - it will not enable the macOS style Form. Unless this is changing this year, there’s no way to get native macOS SwiftUI in Catalyst.

elements.text: From what I understand, this will put Mac controls into the iOS style Form - it will not enable the macOS style Form. Unless this is changing this year, there’s no way to get native macOS SwiftUI in Catalyst.

Hi Jakob!

> However, I'm having a bit of a hard time remembering the syntax. Mostly though, I guess I'm looking for a place to start my own development, for ideas of things to implement to get better at Swift.
I'd recommend not worrying about learning and getting better at Swift or SwiftUI. Instead I'd recommend finding something you're excited to build and... just building it.

I've found when you do that, you end up learning the language syntax and framework APIs without even trying :slightly_smiling_face:
